commentBody:
Just printed the puzzle out to do in the morning.

Am struck by the grid design, interesting.
Lewis, chime in, please!
So... you've been complaining that the puzzles are getting too easy? HA!
Claire Smith is a legend. Great writer.

Super disliking the new histogram. Please put it back the way it was! I want to see my current, average, and best Wednesday all in one. I don‚Äôt need to know whether me Wednesday to Sunday time ratio is different from my average‚Ä¶ I just don‚Äôt get why this change was made!

WHATABLAST!
It's nice to have a Saturday puzzle for a change. 
I love the stacks in the pinwheels.
Some clever clues and interesting answers.
And fair crosses.

Thanks, Katie!
This was a tough one for me! Lots of tough things in it. But I really like the challenge. Please keep having tough Saturday puzzles!

Oh, please. It‚Äôs always either INGE or Agee.  Isn‚Äôt it past time to retire those names to make room for more Oreos and emus?  just taking a break from this very challenging Friday.  Won‚Äôt peek at any spoilers. Thank you.

I thought I was inventing a HOBO spider and it would turn out to be a funny wrong answer. Same deal with the HYENA - ‚Äúoh sure, haha.‚Äù

Oh well, at least there is 50D, which is a funny wrong answer for some who were ABSENT that week.
Tough, but fair. Thanks Katie, this is a beaut!

Okay, maybe it's just bc I'm tired, but I don't get how HORN is "a period ender".  
Help me out here.
This is what the commentariat get after complaining about easy puzzles! Tough but fair. What a doozy ‚Äî er, LULU
Katie and I must have the same ear for wordplay - I chuckled my way through this and solved it relatively smoothly. Lots of guesses in the NE luckily went my way. WHATABLAST! Thanks Katie!
I absolutely loved this one! Crunchy in the most delicious of ways, this was my favorite Saturday challenge in a long time. Thank you so much, Katie!

My jokes about beer are a real brew-haha.

(They're the cure for what ales you.)

Love the clueing on this -- I made a noise like a HYENA for several. 

It was slower than my average, but in my defense I'm on day 2 of a migraine. Had edit before REDO, shAkE before EVADE, WHaP before WHOP (though I knew 17A had to be orchestral so when I had aBOE at the beginning I knew what to change)

Quibble -- Saturn's rings are more of an annulus than a disc. I'm pretty sure they don't intersect the planet, meaning there's no center to it.
A great puzzle! Thank you, Katie!
Lawd that was a workout. Well over my average, but that‚Äôs a gold star to be proud of

This was decently challenging for a Saturday, with good fill overall.

Nice clues for SPEEDCHESS, SETS, HOME BREWER, and a few others.

Names should not cross (INGE and BRUNSON)

8/10
I was stuck for the longest time with ‚ÄúI had a blast‚Äù on my top row. Really had to untangle a bunch to figure out that quadrant.
This is the one I have been waiting for all week - great clueing in this Saturday challenge! Took me twice my average, but I was so pleased that I was able to finish without lookups. Thank you!
Brutal.  Just brutal.
ü•µ phew! Feel like I climbed a mountain with my brain! Definitely got my money's worth! Hard and fun. Great puzzle.

An awesome grid that really stacked up. I truly felt a sense of accomplishment upon completion. 

‚ÄúAdjunct faculty‚Äù for SIXTH SENSE is genius. 

IN SUM, a great puzzle.

Oof, after how easy yesterday's puzzle was, I should have expected something like this. No particular clue or section or even voice stood out to me as especially hard, but there was enough vagueness that things didn't come quickly. I actually had to puzzle things out for a change, and took about 50% longer than average.

I especially liked the clues on SPEED CHESS and SIXTH SENSE, and I think the placement of ICONOCLAST as clued below a clue about Election Day led me directly down the wrong path that I was clearly meant to try before landing on the right interpretation of 'convention'.
Humbled

Hardest puzzle I've seen in a while. Managed to get it under an hour. By six seconds, to be exact. Nothing unfair, just a long, slow trudge until I filled in every last square.

The NW was the last to fall. I had:

I HADABLAST
SODABREWER
WOODSONATA
_D_SE

Hood Spider made sense. Dads support youth baseball. It took me a long time to erase half that section and start over
What a blast indeed. It took me a while but I enjoyed the challenge. Really liked 58A, 26D and 69A. Good trivia too.

Difficult time getting a toehold. Just couldn‚Äôt seem to get on the same wavelength with constructor. It happens sometimes. Maybe a little spoiled by easier puzzles this week. Finished by sheer luck and crossings.  Looking back at clues once I finished, I saw the cleverness of some clues, especially ‚ÄúAdjunct faculty.‚Äù  Nice workout, Katie!
Loved it, great work!

I really enjoyed this one!  Finally a nice engaging puzzle.

I got/guessed 1 across immediately, but it took me about half way through the rest of the grid before I could fill in the rest of that corner.  (I still have reservations about "whop".)

The clue for speed chess was pretty wonderful.  Loved seeing iconoclast as a word, and the accompanying clever misdirection of juxtaposing convention challenger with the political clue above it.

This was good.

Now this was an excellent Saturday crossword! Fantastic clues that really gave my brain a workout, and yet entirely solvable. Nothing seemed like a stretch once I cracked the clue. I struggled with the northwest quadrant. I was certain 1A had to be "I HAD A BLAST," but IHOP did not make much sense for "Smack," although I tried to convince myself that smack was slang for pancake. It wasn't until I tried TEES instead of DEES for "Youth baseball supporters" that 1A came together for me. By the way, that's a great clue for a 4-letter fill; could have been anything from PTAS to DADS to MOMS and ended up being the most literal but surprising option! It also took me a while to give up on SPEEDDATES and think of mate in another way; the C from CLAIRE really helped...which I had to intuit since I'm a sports teetotaler.

Is this normal? Same constructor, same entry, almost the same clue in consecutive grids:

March 22:
39A: Classic Langston Hughes poem quoted on a wall at the National Museum of African American History and Culture: ITOO

July 12:
16A: Classic Langston Hughes poem with a comma in its title: ITOO

Other than that, a complete bloodbath. Ms. Hoody‚Äôs next Saturday will not be EAGERLY AWAITED by me.

Skimmed through the puzzle and immediately got TRAVELOGUE and ICONOCLAST, so I was ready to roll, right?  RIGAMAROLE was more like it.  Got lucky with guess fills like INGE and GUAM, which I didn't really know (Kansas?), and sometimes a beautiful light went on (SPEED CHESS!!), and I was making some headway, but ground to a full stop and finally went for a look-up (I did need some  CLAIRE-ity) but I finished it up, expecting the EAGERLY AWAITED Congratulations!! But no. After scouring the whole puzzle 80 or 90 times, I took the peek offer (groan), and got it done. But right or wrong, "I had A BLAST" anyway!

Katie, your clues, fills, all of it was inspired, and your puzzle was a joy to work. 

The OBOE SONATA! The SIXTH SENSE! The NEST!

Thank you for this puzzle that was so worth the trouble.

I started slow - on my own I was able to get some entries all over the grid, but only the NE quadrant was (almost) complete (how I remembered INGE and that SOONER is a sports thing is anybody's guess).

To be able to progress further I looked up unknown names and trivia: HOBO, AMOS, the EL of ELLIES, the BRU of BRUNSON, DEM, CLAIRE, SULU, and YALE. That generated crosses which allowed me to nearly complete the puzzle.

However, 45 minutes into the solve, with almost the whole grid filled in, I gave up and turned on autocheck to deal with the NW quadrant. The problem was my being 100% confident about iHAdABLAST. I understand WHOP but it's not a word that comes to me naturally, and I have no idea why "Youth baseball supporters" solves to TEES (any help, please? It's not covered by the column). Also, SETS confused me when I finally got it with autocheck on. To me, a set is not an area, but the stuff that gets set up on the area that is a stage... With the error in 1A, I didn't have enough crosses on the downs to solve HOME BREWER. I did get OBOE SONATA though. Is that a thing or a cutesy, crosswordese nod to our favorite instrument, the oboe? BTW, I was quite proud that in the end I remember the use of spot as lend - I learned it from the NYT.

Overall I feel this was a worthy Saturday puzzle for its intended, American audience. For me personally it was too hard to complete without outside help, but I can't say I didn't like it, which is high praise from a Polish curmudgeon ü§£.
Now that was a real treat. A hard Saturday puzzle to start the weekend off right.  Thank you.
Quite the challenge. Like yesterday, lots of names. Almost made me sweat!
yuck

A proper Saturday puzzle! 
Pulling teeth most of the way (in a good way). I was proud to get SIXTHSENSE and SPEEDCHESS with only one letter a piece but the rest came in bits and pieces. A satisfying challenge.

I finished this one with difficulty.. It was great! The turning point was INGE which I knew from Mel Brooks‚Äô ‚ÄúThe Producers‚Äù song ‚ÄúKeep It Gay‚Äù which Max Byalistock sings. Worth a listen on YT

Hated every minute of this. It felt more like a pub quizz filled with trivia (proper noun, proper noun, proper noun) than a difficult Saturday crossword. Any good and challenging clue was drowned in a sea of names. I have to question why, considering how many proper nouns were used, 23D has to be clued as a name rather than the word's general meaning. Compare this puzzle to anything by Robyn Weintraub to see how you can create a challenging crossword that's not exclusive.
too hard for me
Started out hating it then had to like it.  Very clever.  Thanks!

See, this is what happens when you poke the puzzle gods! ‚ÄúSooo‚Ä¶ you think we‚Äôve been too easy on you? Okay, how about THIS?‚Äù

I hope you‚Äôre happy.
Really enjoyed the workout (after a host of easy Fridays and Saturdays in the past couple of years). More of this please!
Fun puzzle!

There must be a scale of enjoyable pain that starts at 1 with light tickling and goes up to 10, where some people apparently get off on whips, chains and Carolina Reaper peppers. I‚Äôd put today‚Äôs puzzle at a 6. I loved it! (Not sure where I go from here?)

Amazing puzzle! The grid was just beautiful to look at. I had almost nothing on the first pass, and a half-hour later I filled in EARL Sweatshirt, for the win. Never heard of him, I‚Äôll have to check out a few songs. Really impressive construction and cluing.

Yes!

Excellent, excellent puzzle. 

TIL it‚Äôs called the GOLDEN GOAL, after having to go back to that corner a few times, looking at _ OL_ _NGOAL  and just not seeing it. Then my brain finally dredged up Diana RIGG. She was hiding behind one neuron without a face or a movie title to go with her name, but there she was anyway. 

SPEED CHESS and SIXTH SENSE clues were brilliant, as was having the clue for ICONOCLAST seem election-themed: With its placement right below ROBODIALER, it made for an ingenious misdirect. 

I am a bit surprised, though, that xwordinfo has the puzzle as ‚Äúvery hard.‚Äù I thought it was beautifully clued and the fill was very fresh but maybe midrange difficulty for a Saturday? Then again, I was very rested, already after 2 cups of coffee and a sugar bomb courtesy of my husband, and I was wearing this new invention on my nose I‚Äôve been getting harangued to use for a year now; it‚Äôs called reading glasses. Did y‚Äôall know that text can be un-smeared with those? A-goshdarn-mazing. 

Have a good weekend, everyone, and thanks for a great puzzle, Katie.
My brain is full now. Back to sleep.

NE corner was just unnecessarily brutal. 

Three long answers in 12/13/14D crossed with 4 proper nouns, a Latin word, an obscure magazine award, and the name of some poem. 

Sheesh man, give us young folk a fighting chance would ya.

Now *that* was a proper Saturday puzzle!  

I put in WHAT A BLAST immediately with no crosses and thought this was going to be a romp, but that was the last answer I had such confidence in for a while.  Fits and starts got it done, and every step was a pleasure.
Each corner felt like a hard fought victory! Loved the challenge of this one, and glad it's Saturday so I could spend more time than usual on it. Bravo!

Well. That was a pencil chewing, brain numbing, frustrating, brilliant grid. I really had to work at this; almost nothing the first few passes, erasing most of what I did fill in as I wasn‚Äôt confident they worked.

I needed all of Caitlin‚Äôs help to get going, but once I‚Äôd got a couple of the long spans the rest slowly became clear. Spent ages looking for an error once I‚Äôd filled the grid, only to find I‚Äôd put lESS instead of NESS for 61D. Witless worked for me! Pretty much how I felt.

A fair scattering of TILs:  sports writers, publishing awards, sing (music?) titles, actors, sports terms (as usual). I queried 13D with DH. Clue and answer quite right, but as Caitlin mentioned, passed over in favour of extra time quite a while ago.

Busy haymaking today; the baler‚Äôs on his way, which means a sweaty afternoon getting them in the stables. Good job I‚Äôve recovered from my bug in time to get attacked by scratchy hay and horse flies. Yay. I need this heatwave to break; too hot to think, let alone do manual labour.

This was the payback for the complaints (who? Me?) that Thursday‚Äôs puzzle was too easy. Very few ‚Äúgimmes‚Äù to get you going, and even those varied from person to person. For me GOLDEN GOAL, RIGG and YALE were all I had to start, after that it was a struggle even as the grid filled. Good mental workout in the end.
Wow. I think that was the hardest puzzle I ever successfully solved. A little bit too much trivia for my taste, but an excellent puzzle nevertheless. The streak is intact! 500 beckons!
1A! Thank you, Katie.
Not only did this puzzle run on Saturday, it is a Saturday-like puzzle.  I'm only halfway through it at this point.

Now that was the very definition of Saturday tough.  So many great clues, like the ones for SIXTHSENSE, OBOESONATA, and HOMEBREWER.  Knowing GOLDENGOAL and having read all of Paul Theroux‚Äôs TRAVELOGUEs is the only thing that gave me enough hope to be able to finish the puzzle.  Theroux is perhaps the most acerbic  travel writer ever, but at least you know you‚Äôre not getting an idealized, sugar coated picture of the places he‚Äôs describing.  His The Great Railway Bazaar turned me on to the joys of travel writing and I‚Äôve followed him around the world ever since.

I had nicu instead of NEST for a while, thinking back to the stressful two and a half weeks my grandson spent in the nicu after being born with a fractured skull.  Nicu nurses and doctors, but especially the nurses, are true heroes.  Caring for infants in distress and managing the hopes and expectations of families during a time of maximum emotional dislocation takes great skill and compassion.

Whew. And Wow! Really tough workout for me, but an amazing piece of construction and some really clever clues. Had to look some things up, but then there were just a lot of nice 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me from the crosses. Eight debut answers but none of those were particularly strange or anything. 

Need to go back and look at Ms. Hoody's previous puzzles. 

And.. puzzle finds today, of course. I'll put those in replies. 

..

Thanks for the puzzle! Spent so long thinking we were in some sort of SPEED DATE situation (or even a SALMON RUN?), which already would have been a clever clue. Thev actually solution was amazing and helped me to finish up the puzzle. So much clever wordplay in these, and I learned some fun facts!

Tricky!  Interesting grid, the middle section effectively made it almost like four separate puzzles blocked off from each other.  Started off in the NE and went clockwise, with each quadrant getting a little harder than the last.

Oh my.  Here it is.  Beauty, humor, wit, and skill at the top level in the box today.  The art and science of the crossword puzzle paradigmed for our viewing and solving pleasure.  

Even before filling in the first square, that gorgeous grid.  It reminds me of those fireworks that transform through various colors, and end with a matrix of popping dot-like flashes.  There‚Äôs that matrix centering the grid.  Those black squares are not random, as this grid has both 90- and 180-degree symmetry. 

So, Katie started with the grid design rather than let it change during the grid build.  That can be constricting, but this answer set shows no strain, no hints of desperation.  No, it shines and shimmers with beauty, unblemished.

Look at those triple-stack 10s!  Every one of them interesting, adding spark.  Six of them have never graced the Times puzzle before ‚Äì GO EASY ON ME, GOLDEN GOAL, HOME BREWER, OBOE SONATA, ROBO DIALER, WHAT A BLAST.

And the cluing!  A clinic. Not only searing wordplay and wit ‚Äì [Adjunct faculty?] for SIXTH SENSE, are you kidding me? ‚Äì but even mini clue themes, like three involving the word ‚Äúspot‚Äù.  Misdirects, sparkling riddles, clues that yield several answers, like [Zip] ‚Äì is it meaning ‚Äúnothing‚Äù or ‚Äúspark‚Äù?

I came in with great hope, as your last puzzle had me singing high praises, Katie, and my hope was more than met.  Thank you for a marvelous outing.  You can be sure that your next one is EAGERLY AWAITED.  Bring it on!

I don‚Äôt know our constructor, so will have to be inclusive in trying out the title I thought of for them:
M(i)s(s/sus/tress/ter) Direction.

*sigh*

What a great puzzle! I loved all the lingo.
This was a tough and clever puzzle!  I needed all the help I could get to solve!  Thanks everyone

Yes, pretty tough, with clever clues, I can see why lots of people liked this one. 

Some unfamiliar terms, like BRUNSON, ELLIES, CLAIRE; ITALIAN SUB is probably easy for those in the US. Sigh. The only one I just can't figure out is RIVAL. Hope someone can help.
Started pretty well, got some big fills right off the bat. But then was completely flummoxed by the incredibly obscure ones. LULU? Not fun.
I completed it somehow. There there was a lot that I'd never heard of and was just guessing .

Whew...That was a workout.
Finished with no help in just under an hour.
I need a nap!
Sometimes you hit a puzzle that is just not on your wavelength. This one was like that for me.

No complaints from me, though that completely stumped me. Yesterday I knew all the trivia, today I knew zilch. A couple of passes through the grid left me with only 2 or 3 answers filled in. Trying to resist lookups, I decided that reading Letter from a Birmingham Jail was the best kind of cheating so I spent a while doing that. And then looked up everything else I could. And then turned on autocheck. I scrolled through the song titles of 18 Glenn Miller albums on Spotify and didn‚Äôt find it. I wouldn‚Äôt have gotten WHOP in a million years, don‚Äôt think I have ever heard that before. This puzzle well and truly bested me. As, you know, Saturday should.

Can we just acknowledge that proper names of people are like proper names of places? They are Naticks. Worse, they are usually ancient celebrities, further making NYTXW exclusive to specific demographics ü¶ï

This one seemed like a Saturday puzzle to me. Solved it unaided, but took me half an hour. 

Went wrong early with NICU for "Spot for newborn care". Until it occurred to me (Thanks, Barry A.) that nothing in the clue was abbreviated.

"Terms of a trade" was very clever for LINGO, as was "Adjunct faculty?" for SIXTHSENSE (which might have been even better without the question mark). Got HYENA quickly for "Member of a sub-Saharan matriarchal clan", though only after trying to squeeze in some sort of elephant. "Rush to find a mate?" for SPEEDCHESS was also cute, as was "Sooner, to a Longhorn" for RIVAL. That said, "Wit's end?" for NESS was a bit much.

RIGAMAROLE looks strange to me. I'm more familiar with RIGMAROLE. On the other hand, ICONOCLAST is a great word.

Hope we can have more Saturday puzzles like this one---unless my reading of the comments now reveals that everyone found it much too easy.  ;-)
Toughest NYT puzzle in ages. I loved it!!!
I still don‚Äôt get SIXTHSENSE. Can someone enlighten me?
I have to say, that was by far the hardest puzzle on NYT I have ever actually completed without help.  It was a real challenge, thanks.

I knew that "Shape of Saturn's rings" was going to be either DISk or DISC. My reasoning was that DISk was the preferred American spelling, except in certain specific cases (like in medicine), and that if the British spelling were being used there would be some indication of that. Probably it's usually spelled with a "C" by astronomers, but I was unaware of that. So I stuck a "K" in there, then forgot that there was any uncertainty and thought that DISk was a sure thing.

Which left me looking at the answer to "Detective, at times" to be T__kER. I had no idea. I finally just looked it up.

(This was particularly galling to me since my father, at different periods of his life, was an insurance adjuster back in the days when they actually thoroughly investigated claims, a private detective, and a skip tracer. He once brought me with him when he was doing surveillance on some guy, because a lone man sitting in a car for an extended period sticks out like a sore thumb, but a man sitting in a car with a kid goes unquestioned. As a kid there's nothing like sitting in a hot car on a summer day for five hours or so trying to make conversation with your dad.)

I've had music theory classes. I've had private lessons for cello. I'm currently going on three years of classical guitar lessons. But I've never had a class that was just titled MUSIC. I'm sure they exist, though. It sounds like a bunch of bored five year olds thumping tambourines and little drums in time to a recording.
Tough one. I spent a lot of time trying to figure out what "Smack" has to do with IHOP and if Americans call dads DEES in junior sport events, until it dawned on me...

I had to look up about half a dozen of the proper nouns. But the word plays were all soluble even for a Brit who doesn't have television. (Hence my not knowing Diana Rigg was in the new All Creatures Great and Small.

A couple of spelling errors had me hunting to get the gold star today. Had ‚ÄúRIGAMeROLE‚Äù before correcting it, and didn‚Äôt know the proper spelling of Quinta‚Äôs last name, so had it as ‚ÄúBRUNSeN,‚Äù for a while. That last one kept me from figuring out the ‚ÄúGOLDEN GOAL‚Äù / ‚ÄúLINGO‚Äù crossing. 

Definitely a challenging puzzle, all around. Glad to have to work for it today. Well done, Ms. Hoody!

The best Saturday puzzle in recent memory.  Excellent, challenging, clever cluing. Lots of word play. 

Absolutely loved it!
If I loved this puzzle any more I‚Äôd need a cigarette.

Spent way too long trying to get truant (missed music) for ABSENT and tvads (spots) for LENDS to work. Even doubted AWAITED for a while. 

A real workout. Knowing AMOS and HOBO would have made the upper left side a lot easier. 

The rest was par for the course.

Enough!  No mas!  I can't take it any more!  I'm outta here!

Well. many of you have been clamoring for a really tough end-of-week puzzle -- and you certainly got one today.  At least I thought so.

I couldn't start in the NW, so I started lower down, hoping I'd be able to fill it in later.  And with enormous effort, I was.  This was going to be a keep the faith solve, just as I had hoped.

Except it wasn't.  Because now I couldn't get anything in the SE other than ICONOCLAST and ETHICS.

ETHICS gave me the H of the matriarchal clan.  I thought it was one of those tribes -- HUTSI or HUTTI or something like that.  The U gave me UCLA instead of YALE for the SCOTUS school.  Who on earth would think of an animal, a HYENA, as a member of a "clan"?

But I should have known that 9 out of every 10 Supreme Court Justices went to YALE.

Anyway, I bailed.  I couldn't sit and stare at this grid forever.  It was making me absolutely crazy.
I've realised I can't figure out NESS - please help.
Yeah, that pretty much defeated me.  Just when I thought I was getting good at Friday, Saturday comes to humble me.
This felt like an old-school puzzle, in a positive way. Quite difficult but not unreasonably so or Natick-y. Congratulations and thank you to Katie!

I had three (count 'em, THREE) entries on my first pass....and one of them was wrong.  (Parents who have had a newborn in the NICU on life support are never really "over it.")

This was certainly a LULU.
Did you ever trying SPEED DATES?
I was grateful for my Freshman year of Old Testament...for PBS....for the Bront√©s..  
I guess we need to watch more sitcoms?  Not sure we will.

Ave atque VALE.

Ooof, what a noodle-scratcher!

After several passes through the clues with little to show for it, feeling very similar to when I started puzzling, I allowed myself some look-ups. üòÜ

It brought me back to when I‚Äôd learn all sorts of new things while trying to solve a puzzle, by having to look up people and terms and ideas. I‚Äôd get lost in rabbit holes and while it made for slower puzzling, I enjoyed expanding my views. This is how I learned about some common crossword topics like the Harlem Renaissance, WNBA teams, and different types of tides. What fun!

I would have been immensely frustrated had I been in a rush this morning. But it was a lovely puzzle that used such clever wordplay that I couldn‚Äôt hold a grudge (after a few searches of names of matriarchal societies in Africa, none of which fit the grid, I realized - HYENA - and my reaction reminds me that I could never be described by the clue for 65D).
Important law school class: ETHICS.  Hmm?  Who knew?

The early commenters have said it all, so I will just thank Ms. Hoody for a creative, challenging and oh so satisfying puzzle.  WHAT A BLAST!

Also, it‚Äôs fun to see how each of us found our own way in to the grid, through one or two remembered footholds or inspired guesses, with no two entry points the same!

I had all but NW corner and then was pretty well stuck. AWAITED I had going for me, but I doubted myself and tried TURBULENCE (high winds) and TRUANT (skipping music) which sent me off on the wrong track for a while.

For the first time in quite awhile, I needed Google to help me with a couple of spots. Not knowing the sub-Saharan tribe, wit-LESS was a perfectly reasonable entry at the cross so I would never have gotten the music without a little help. A wonderful Saturday workout that I needed to walk away from/return to in order to align my synapses.
INSUM and WHOPS ..... I absolutely hated this puzzle.
Well done, Katie!
Really tough for me, but plodding along I finally finished with no lookups, and way over average time. SW last to go. Might have been faster if I hadn‚Äôt had SPEEDbrEed pencilled in‚Ä¶

I loved this puzzle! After many years of solving crossword puzzles, I rarely encounter this much resistance. I struggled, I filled in so many wrong first, second, and third guesses, and I cheated (which I refer to as "learning new things") by looking stuff up. I finished in a time that was more like what I used to experience every week in my early days of being able to solve Saturday puzzles. Thank you so much for the challenge!

Man, what a beast! Well over an hour, one of those where I really didn‚Äôt know how I would finish. About half that time spent in the NW. 

So many misdirects there:

NICU for newborn care
OVAL for Saturn‚Äôs rings
CADENT for skipping music (I was thinking jump rope)
ODEA for staging areas

What a mess. 

Anyone else have CUPS for Youth baseball supporters? Hey, I played Little League. 

I guess this was more like the Saturday puzzles of old. That was a doozy!
Are Katie Hoody and EARL Sweatshirt related?

Wow. Took my wife, SIL, and I 2 hours to solve with no lookups today. Really tough!

Not a bad experience when you‚Äôre drinking Campari Spritzes on vacation in Milan, though :)
I had totally given up, but decided to go to the Farmers Market to see if walking away and coming back gave me new insight to the lower left. and it worked!

I guessed HOBO, which was good, but was more confident about silENT for [Skipping music] (like a silent move maybe? It somehow made sense at the moment), so that was a wash. I finally gave up on silENT and chipped away until I opened things up with iHAdABLAST (insert record scratch sound effect here). I really struggled to justify friend-of-the-crossword iHOP for [Smack] before another round of scratch and patch put paid to that corner. 

Similar stories across the other 80% of the puzzle. Tough one!
Perfect Saturday gem.   Just challenging enough.  I "eagerly await" your next one, Katie!

That was a workout! Loved it. I was tempted to look stuff up but persevered. My entry was RIVAL, ITOO, VALE from there I inferred RIGG, ITALIAN something and ALDA. The NE filled in, I went looking for stepping stones across the grid and they were really far apart. Mine were ADEN, EYRE, YALE, ARTE, EGOS and TEES. 
I had MODS before REFS, NICU and TEAT (from the E&T) before NEST and WHAM before WHOP. 
HYENA  from the -Y-NA required a completely different species consideration from my knowledge of sub Saharan tribes. 
IN SUM I think this grid and its clues are a masterpiece, thank you Katie Hoody.
Bravo. This puzzle was a REFRESHING and challenging ride. Hats off to Katie. You rule!

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened - first a Sunday from August 12, 2001 by Nancy Nicholson Joline with the title "In crowd." This was pretty amazing. 22 rebus squares - all of them the letters 'IN'. Some sample theme answers: ICHB(IN)E(IN)BERL(IN)ER STR(IN)GBIK(IN)IS SP(IN)ET(IN)GL(IN)G THERA(IN)(IN)SPA(IN) AFTERD(IN)NERM(IN)TS (IN)SIDERTRAD(IN)G MART(IN)IDR(IN)KER And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/12/2001&g=99&d=A ...

@Rich in Atlanta And - one more really amazing puzzle. I've never seen another like this. A Sunday from May 16, 2010 by Matt Ginsberg with the title: "Double Crossers." This one is hard to describe, but the trick here was rebus squares that had 2 letters stacked above 2 other letters, so that both the crossing and down answers each repeated that string by alternating the top and bottom for the across answers and left and right for the down answers. Some examples as best I can render them with the rebus squares in parentheses. FA(ST)ER (TH) E F A N So the implied across answers was FA(ST)ERFA(TH)ER and the down answer (ST)EFAN(TH)EFAN Some other examples. Across; (ST)AINER (TR)AINER down (ST)UCK (TR)UCK Across: INTHE(RE)D INTHE(EN)D Down (RE)TRY (EN)TRY And just some other examples: (SP)ATTER/(PL)ATTER CONT(RI)TION/CONT(EN)TION CH(EA)TER/CH(AT)ER P(EA)CH/P(AT)CH COOK(IE)/COOK(ER) And there were lots more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/16/2010&g=80&d=A I'm done. ....

A Natick is when *two* answers you don't know cross, and even if you fill most of the letters from crosses, you can't infer or intuit the square where they cross.

I have three guitars. One is an Alhambra 4P. 2)VALE is the conventional parting sentiment in Latin, but it means "goodbye" as in "be good/well," as in "farewell." But the verb can also be used as greeting--a common letter-opener was "Si vales, bene est; ego valeo"--"If you're well, that is good; I am well myself"--conventional to the point of being abbreviated SVBEEG--now wouldn't *that* be an intitialism to show up in the puzzle! the stock greeting "Ave" of course means "hail"--so the phrase "Ave atque vale"--immortalized by Catullus--"hail and farewell"--could also mean "hello/goodbye"!
